description: From Middle English secrette, from Old French secret, from Latin sēcrētus (“separated, hidden”), from ptp of sēcernō (“separate, to set aside, sunder out”), from cernō, from Proto-Indo-European *krey-. Displaced  Old English dēagol (“secret”) and dēagolnes (“a secret”).

adjectives.description: secret (comparative more secret, superlative most secret)

entries.meaning: Being or kept hidden. [from late 14th c.]
examples: We went down a secret passage.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Withdrawn from general intercourse or notice; in retirement or secrecy; secluded.
(obsolete) Faithful to a secret; not inclined to divulge or betray confidence; secretive, separate, apart.

examples: They suppose two other divine hypostases superior thereunto, which were perfectly secret from matter.

entries.meaning: (countable) A piece of knowledge that is hidden and intended to be kept hidden. [from late 14th c.]
examples: "Can you keep a secret?" "Yes." "So can I."

entries.meaning: The key or principle by which something is made clear; the knack.
examples: The secret to a long-lasting marriage is compromise.
The work was done in secret, so that nobody could object.

entries.meaning: (archaic, in the plural) The genital organs.

(Christianity, often in the plural) Any prayer spoken inaudibly and not aloud; especially, one of the prayers in the Tridentine Mass, immediately following the "orate, fratres", said inaudibly by the celebrant.

verbs.description: secret (third-person singular simple present secrets, present participle (UK) secretting or (US) secreting, simple past and past participle (UK) secretted or (US) secreted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make or keep secret. [from late 16th c.]
examples: [...] she would unfold the silk, press it with a smooth wooden block that she'd heated in the oven, and then once more secret it away.
He was so scared for his safety he secreted arms around the house.
